Council Refuses to Endorse Coalition Demands
by Kathleen McCarthy
The Student Council, at last
Wednesday night's meeting, rejected motions to endorse the
Coalition for a Free South
Africa's recent demands from the
University.
The demands—that the University Trustees release the minutes
of their board meeting of October
27 in which they voted not to fully
divest, and that a binding referendum be taken of the entire University—were introduced separately. Both motions were defeated
by a simple majority.
The Coalition for a Free South
Africa sent three members,
Jonathon Epner, Tom Hall and
Bijoy Matheu, to present their request for Council endorsement.
Hall argued "The referendum is
not ridiculous, idealistic. . . it
would be a step towards logical
democratization of the University. It has a legal precedent. . .in,
I believe, 1973, on the issue of
marine recruitment on campus, a
binding referendum was taken."
Hall demanded on the request for
the Trustees' minutes, saying
"The Trustees have a policy of
secrecy from the people they are
supposedly representing."
Junior Class President Sahir
Surmeli questioned, "Why
haven't the minutes of Trustee
board meetings been made public
in the past'? Is it because they are
afraid people will manipulate
them from the outside?" Senior
Class Representative Brad Marks
wondered, "Is is practical for the
Trustees to give up their fiduciary
responsibility, to give it up to the
University as a whole in a binding
referendum'?"
Hall replied, "The morality of
this issue dictates that the Student
Council should endorse our call
for a binding referendum, whether it is practical or not. . .
the Trustees have already made a
moral statement on this issue by
agreeing to go along with the
Sullivan Principles. . . so there is
'moral precedent'." Matheu added, "They [the Trustees] do want
to do...the right thing, you
can't divorce morality from
fiduciary responsibility."
Sophomore Class Representative Jonathan Hubbard queried,
"I'm wondering about the technique. . . who are you including [in
the referendum vote]?" Sophomore Class President Scott FitzGerald offered "As far as I'm
concerned, I think you guys
should probably get the minutes
if the Trustees have something to
hide. But I can safely say that the
students are not informed enough
to vote [in such a referendum]."
Freshman Class Representative
Daryl Flaherty said, "I don't
think we want to set a precedent
for the University. I don't want
to say that students should have
a hand in administration."
Matheu, clarifying his position,
said, "We are saying that this
issue is so important it can't be
left in the hands of businessmen,
it's an issue that is not just fiscal.
We feel that how the University
acts should reflect student
opinion."
Junior Class Representative
Damien Doute proposed the motion: "We, the Student Council
of Johns Hopkins University,
support the request of the Coalition For a Free South Africa for

the minutes of the Trustees board
meeting of 10-27-86."
SC Treasurer Dave Shade ventured, "I don't feel qualified to
understand everything the
Trustees say." Flaherty maintained, "I don't know enough about
why the Trustees have secrecy at
their meeting—the Coalition
needs to provide more information on that."
Flaherty moved to table the
motion indefinitely. The move
failed. The motion was then voted
on and failed.
FitzGerald then proposed a second motion: "We, .the Student
Council, endorse the Coalition's
call for a binding referendum of
the entire Johns Hopkins community."
Flaherty again protested,
"These issues are just raised
tonight, we talk about them for a
half hour, hour. . . it doesn't seem

to me that all objective information has been presented." Shade
questioned, "Who's going to
vote? You haven't laid down the
ground rules of this referendum.
We are just supporting a blank
referendum."
Junior Class Representative
Ken Kimura, referring to the
Coalition's argument that such a
referendum would be a logical
step towards democratization,
said, "This is a college campus—
not a democracy. There is no
reason why we should have the
right to make a binding resolution."
This second motion was voted
on and failed.
There was some argument
afterwards, chiefly articulated by
FitzGerald and Freshman Class
Representative George Lerner,
that not enough time had been
given to discussing both sides of

Phi Psi 500 Takes-In $1300
To Assist Local Santa Claus
by Lisa Weisbord
Despite last Saturday's had
weather, the sixth annual "Phi
Psi 500" earned over $1300
which will be donated to Santa
Claus Anonymous, a local charity which assists Baltimore needy
during the Christmas season. This
sum is close to $150 more than
last year's event brought in. According to Dave Battleman, a Phi
Kappa Psi brother who.organized this year's 500, "About eight
teams that had signed up, but
hadn't paid, didn't show up. This
may have been because of the
weather and it caused us to lose
some money."
This year over thirty teams
pariticipated in the day's contests.
Teams consisted of five members
who each paid a five dollar en-

trance fee. In return, all participants recieived a free tee-shirt,
compliments of Bestway Distributors and an invitation to Phi
Psi's annual "500 Party." According to Battleman, "Although
there were more participants this
year than last year, the increased
earnings were due in part to an
expanded sale of tee-shirts."
These pseudo-Olympic games
were held Saturday, November 1,
on the Gilman Quad. The event,
which is among the largest
student-run charity fundraisers at
the University, featured team
games which consisted of bed
races, bat relays, trunk-to-tail
relays and a water balloon toss.
Mark Rouchard, the President
of Santa Claus Anonymous, attended last weekend's event and
"expressed his appreciation" for

helping his organization to
function.
"The 500 had a number of very
generous sponsors," said Battleman. Armand's Chicago Pizzaria provided free dinners for the
winning teams. This year's winners included the Pink Flamingos, Phi Mu 2, Rolling Stone
and Raspberry Death.
Bestway Distributors supplied
the tee-shirts and Union Sound
donated the equipment for the
music which filled Gilman Quad
on Saturday afternoon. Seilers
Food Service donated chips and
soda and Circle K provided hot
chocolate. The Student Activities
Board contributed school tables
for the 500's use and Eddie's
Supermarkets helped sponsor the
posters.

Rubik's Magic Foiled By Student's Math Wizardry
hy Ashu Handa
Ashwin Belur, a Johns Hopkins
University mathematics major
from the class of '85, became an
overnight media sensation by
publishing the solution book to
Dr. Erno Rubik's new puzzle,
"Rubik's Magic."
Belur, along with fellow
University of Pennsylvania
graduate student Blair Whitaker,
received the puzzle from a
retailer three weeks ago, solved
it, and wrote a manuscript within
a week. They then contacted Dell
Publishers in New York, who
agreed to print it.
Meanwhile, the Hungarian inventor, beaten at his own game by
two college students, is suing
Belur, Whitaker, and Dell
Publishing Company for violating
his trademark, patent, and

copyrights. "I don't like that,"
said Rubik bitterly, after first
hearing about the new book.
Rubik had intended to publish his
own solution book early next
year.
The legal confrontation that
Belur and his friend's ingenuity
has provoked will only create
more media attention. The two
authors have already been interviewed by major news agencies
in the nation and have had stories
published in the New York Times,
the Sun, and Newsweek
magazine. To top it all, they
appeared on Good Morning
America last Monday, November
3, but Belur wants even more.
"I want to get on David Letterman," said Belur with a
cheeky grin on his face.
Letterman or not, one thing is
certain: these two will not be

writing home for money
anymore. Their book, with all the
attention given to it, is already
selling at a best-seller rate and is
scheduled to reach the shops in
the first week of November. That
is, unless Rubik gets his way.
Rubik will try and delay the
release of the book to the general
public with legal action. "It's my
idea, my work," said the inventor. "It's completely unauthorized. I'm disappointed and surprised the authors or the publishers
didn't contact me."
The literary agents and
publishers of Belur declined to
comment, but a spokesman for
the puzzle's manufacturers, Matchbox Toys U.S.A. proclaimed,
"They're using someone else's
work as a launching pad. We
have every intention of protecting
not only our patent, but also the

name that goes with it."
Belur first got the idea for the
book when he heard about the
puzzle over the radio this summer. He remembered that after
the "Rubik's Cube— was released, there were three solution
books to the puzzle on the New
York Times Best-Seller list
following Christmas. "I knew
somebody was going to write a
book and somebody was going to
have a bestseller. I figured it
might as well be me," he
explained.
The students started a
scavenger hunt for a copy of the
puzzle in late August, and finally received a promotional copy on
Sept. 22. They then started their
marathon quest for the solution,
which eventually took them 50
hours. Belur found an agent
through a friend in a Penn

cafeteria. Dell, a division of
Doubleday, agreed to publish it,
and the rest became a whirlwind
tour in the fast lane, with almost
daily trips to New York, T.V.
and newspaper interviews, and
autograph hounds.
James Stein, the students' agent
explained, "It's a fantasy come
true. There's a big market for it,
a big market. Now hopefully,
they'll make a fair amount of
money.
Jessica Reed, a fellow student
and friend of Belur's at Hopkins
declared, "Ashwin is like that
sometimes--he'll pick up an idea
and become entranced with it, not
forgetting it until it has exhausted
him." Rita Sun, another close
friend of Belur's at Hopkins.
agreed. "I'm not really that surprised this happened to Aswhin."

Interest In South African Protest Rallies Wanes
(CPS)—Protests of college investment in companies that do
business in segregationist South
Africa came off as planned last
week on about 50 American campuses, but some protest leaders
think college interest in the issue
may be waning.
Demonstrations at Dartmouth,
Southern Cal, North Carolina,
Wesleyan, Toledo, Texas and
some other campuses were
notably smaller than antiapartheid protests held on the
same campuses last April and last
October.
"I think there's been a decline
in interest in divestment this
fall," says Glenn Maloney, assistant to the dean of students at the
University of Texas at Austin.
Last week's protest drew only
50 students, compared to more
than 300 at a rally last April,
which—like the recent October
rallies—was coordinated as part
of a National Day of Protest staged by the American Committee
on Africa in New York.

Crowd size at the University of
Illinois was down to 50 to 75 people last week, reports political
science major Teresa Cameron,
compared to 150 last spring.
At Wesleyan in Connecticut,
police last April arrested about
130 students involved in a
blockade of the administration
building. Last week, about 20
students staged a sit-in, while 100
others listened quietly to antiapartheid speakers. There were
no arrests.
Dartmouth's anti-apartheid
speeches drew 125 students, professors and local residents,
estimates Dartmouth spokesman
Alex Huppe, compared to "300
to 500 people" last spring.
But Kay McKenzie, a faculty
member and organizer of last
week's demonstration at the
University of Mississippi, says
she's happy with the turnout of
150 students.
"The issue is just catching on
here," she says. "Mississippi is
a very conservative place. They

don't change that quickly."
McKenzie does think the issue
may be waning mostly in places
where it's been big for a few
years now.
Anti-apartheid protests have
been going on on some campuses
since the early 1970's, but
abruptly became a national

phenomenon in January, 1985. In
April and May, 1985, a College
Press Service count found nearly
200 campuses hosting some kind
of anti-apartheid activity. The
American Committee on Africa
estimated about 100 campuses
joined its April, 1986 effort.
Some observers blamed the

weather for last week's diminished turnouts. At Illinois, Cameron
noted the protest came during
midterm's week.
More than 50 schools have
agreed to divest partially or fully
so far in 1986, a record pace.

Historian Robert K. Massie, author of Peter the Great and
Nicholas and Alexandra, lectured last Wednesday evening in
Shriver Auditorium on the topic "Participating in History." The
lecture was sponsored by the Frederick Jackson Turner Society,
and Massie was introduced by A .J.R. Russell-Wood, professor
of history at Hopkins.
Massie, who is regarded as a major scholar in his field of modern
European history, is a 1950 graduate of Yale and attended Oxford
as a Rhodes Scholar. After serving in the Navy, Massie worked
on the staff of Collier's and Newsweek, as a book reviewer, foreign
news writer, and United Nations correspondent.
His writing has appeared in several national periodicals including

Barnstormers Production: Arsenic and Old Lace
by Loren Fox
by Joseph Kesselring
Directed by David Deboy
Produced by Carol Gerry and
Jim Stofan
The theme of the old Alfred
Hitchcock Hour begins, and the
piano is moved aside to add seats.
Saturday night and it is standing
room only in the L/V room for
the Barnstormers' production of
Arsenic and Old Lace. The
1940's farce by Joseph Kesselring remains a stodgy classic in
old-fashioned American comedy.
In the Barnstormers' production,
the play moves a little stiffly
around the joints, but old as it is,
it gets the laughs out.
The first thing to notice is Andy Angelino's wonderful set. Not
only is there a wall lined with
bookcases, paintings, and three
working doors, but there is actually a second floor--complete
with a carpeted staircase. The
Listening/Viewing
Room
(designed for neither listening nor
viewing) is a terrible theater, but
the Arsenic set transcends even
that.
The play begins in the Brewster
home in Brooklyn. Abby
Brewster (Kelli Midgley) and her
sister Martha (Alice Griffin) live
in the house taking care of their
nephew Teddy (Scott McNamee).
Abby and Martha make chicken
broth for sick neighbors and help

whenever they can, and Teddy
thinks that he is Theodore
Roosevelt. Policemen come over
to collect old toys for the
Christmas fund, and there is a
dead body in the window seat. It's
as nice and cozy as Our Town
turned inside out.
The two aunts are lively, sweet
and overly bubbly, as if they had
stepped out from an imitation
Norman Rockwell. But Abby and
Martha also mix elderberry wine
with arsenic and cyanide, and
feed it to lonely old men looking
to rent a room. They've been doing this some while and there are
now eleven bodies in the cellar,
in graves dug by Teddy, who
thinks he is digging locks for the
Panama Canal. Another nephew,
Mortimer (Vince Li Cata) is a
theater critic and sane (if one can
be both). He is in love with the
Preacher's daughter, Elaine
(Carol Gerry). Mortimer finds
out about the elderberry wine and
decides it is time to stop it. As he
puts it: "This is becoming a very
bad habit."
Arsenic and Old Lace is a play
of double-takes; the ordinary is
shifted just slightly out of focus.
The great joy is the spoof of
mysteries—the audience can
relish in knowing something the
actors don't. Mortimer is a real
sharp-tongued journalist in the
tradition of The Front Page. Li
Cata plays him as a nervous,
quirky intellectual. He makes

wonderful cracks about criticism,
such as, "I can save time if I
write my review on the way to the
theater." Or he says to a colleague, "I was just feeling a
bit. . .Pirandellish."
In Act Two, the other nephew
comes home. Jonathan Brewster
(Chris Barrett) returns after
traveling the world murdering
people. He returns with a jumpy
surgeon known as Dr. Einstein
(Jeremy Golub). In the film,
Einstein was played by Peter
Lorre, but Golub makes the part
his own. Jonathan, who was
made to look like Boris Karloff
after some of Einstein's plastic
surgery, wants to move back
home and set up a plastic surgery
shop. "Practically everybody in
Brooklyn needs a new face," he
explains. These two have brought
their own corpse, and the comedy
ensues.
The aunts work in their own
perfectly logical fashion,
endeavoring to help friendless old
gentlemen find "peace." When
Mortimer says, "There are 12
men in the cellar and you admit
you've poisoned them," Abby
replies: "Yes, I did. But I
wouldn't stoop to lying."
Midgley's great asset is her
voice, fluttering like the old lace
decorating her home. She is just
a slightly better comedienne than
Griffin, who nevertheless is an
excellent, if slightly posed, actress. When the twelfth body is

hidden in the window seat, they
tell Teddy to keep it a secret. He
thinks a moment, then
McNamee's eyes light up, "A
state secret?" McNamee is a
very funny Teddy, not overplaying the role, yet keeping him off
the wall enough so that the audience looks forward to his next
entrance.
Mortimer tries to explain to
Elaine that he can't marry her
because of his heritage. "Insanity runs in my family. In fact, it
practically gallops." There is
good chemistry between them,
though Li Cata (with his Jimmy
Stewart awkwardness) is at first
overpowered by Gerry. Gerry
comes on strong with her be-bop
hairstyle and expressive mouth.
Li Cata, with wild facial expressions, voice cracking and
browline jumping, is a frantically witty Mortimer, yet he lacks
the presence to make a realistic
foil for Jonathan.
As Jonathan, Chris Barrett
fumes, sneers and boils. Unfortunately the play doesn't allow for
his character to explode, and he
is kept within a limited range. Except for some trouble with his
lines, Barrett comes off well. Accolades are due for Jeremy
Golub, a physical actor par excellence. With eyebrows twitching and eyes rolling, Golub
steals almost every scene he is in.
All eyes are on Golub's mimicking of Elaine as Jonathan

threatens her, and the funniest
scene of the night is when Einstein tries to get out of the window
seat.
The supporting cast is competent although the play gives them
little in the way of character.
Glenn White is sufficiently suffocating as a playwriting cop, and
Jason Hanson is bothersome as a
pompous policemen with an innocuous smirk plastered to his
face. The script itself drags a little in parts. Arsenic really is too
long a play, but one sits through
it to see some fine examples of
humor, as when Jonathan
discovers that the aunts have killed twelve men, just as he has.
"Johnny," Einstein says,
"We've been chased all over the
world. And they [Abby and Martha] stayed in Brooklyn and did
just as good as you."
Director David Deboy (who
did last fall's Hot L Baltimore: the
Barnstormers' choice of plays
needs work) paces it a bit too
slowly. There need to be more
coincidences, as when Elaine hits
Jonathan in the face with the
door. Besides some faltering
lights and some fragile props, the
production runs smoothly. Punch
and cookies during the intermission is a nice touch—the Barnstormers have turned in a class
act. So, could theater at Hopkins
finally becoming into its own?
Maybe, but first, have a glass of
elderberry wine.

memoirs of Victor Mehta (Alexander Zale), a conservative and
controversial Indian novelist who
was brought up in England. The
fact that Hare has chosen to call
him "Mehta" is interesting in the

Those who say cancer research

The center, along with the entire

eradicate the disease.
The personnel at the Oncology
and Pharmacology Center range

covers the full range of cancer

Scientists at the Johns Hopkins
Children's Center are perfecting

fibrosis (CF). This new procedure is convenient and

tests. Physicians hope to use the
technique to identify CF patients
who need enzyme supplements to
aid in their digestion.
CF is a relatively common

disease. The disease inflicts permanent lung damage, and plugs

carry digestive enzymes into the
small intestine.

seizure origins without the need
for invasive surgery.

slow or even stop the cancer process of uncontrolled cell division.

Rubik's Magic Foiled By Student's Math Wizardry
hy Ashu Handa
Ashwin Belur, a Johns Hopkins
University mathematics major
from the class of '85, became an
overnight media sensation by
publishing the solution book to
Dr. Erno Rubik's new puzzle,
"Rubik's Magic."
Belur, along with fellow
University of Pennsylvania
graduate student Blair Whitaker,
received the puzzle from a
retailer three weeks ago, solved
it, and wrote a manuscript within
a week. They then contacted Dell
Publishers in New York, who
agreed to print it.
Meanwhile, the Hungarian inventor, beaten at his own game by
two college students, is suing
Belur, Whitaker, and Dell
Publishing Company for violating
his trademark, patent, and

copyrights. "I don't like that,"
said Rubik bitterly, after first
hearing about the new book.
Rubik had intended to publish his
own solution book early next
year.
The legal confrontation that
Belur and his friend's ingenuity
has provoked will only create
more media attention. The two
authors have already been interviewed by major news agencies
in the nation and have had stories
published in the New York Times,
the Sun, and Newsweek
magazine. To top it all, they
appeared on Good Morning
America last Monday, November
3, but Belur wants even more.
"I want to get on David Letterman," said Belur with a
cheeky grin on his face.
Letterman or not, one thing is
certain: these two will not be

writing home for money
anymore. Their book, with all the
attention given to it, is already
selling at a best-seller rate and is
scheduled to reach the shops in
the first week of November. That
is, unless Rubik gets his way.
Rubik will try and delay the
release of the book to the general
public with legal action. "It's my
idea, my work," said the inventor. "It's completely unauthorized. I'm disappointed and surprised the authors or the publishers
didn't contact me."
The literary agents and
publishers of Belur declined to
comment, but a spokesman for
the puzzle's manufacturers, Matchbox Toys U.S.A. proclaimed,
"They're using someone else's
work as a launching pad. We
have every intention of protecting
not only our patent, but also the

name that goes with it."
Belur first got the idea for the
book when he heard about the
puzzle over the radio this summer. He remembered that after
the "Rubik's Cube— was released, there were three solution
books to the puzzle on the New
York Times Best-Seller list
following Christmas. "I knew
somebody was going to write a
book and somebody was going to
have a bestseller. I figured it
might as well be me," he
explained.
The students started a
scavenger hunt for a copy of the
puzzle in late August, and finally received a promotional copy on
Sept. 22. They then started their
marathon quest for the solution,
which eventually took them 50
hours. Belur found an agent
through a friend in a Penn

cafeteria. Dell, a division of
Doubleday, agreed to publish it,
and the rest became a whirlwind
tour in the fast lane, with almost
daily trips to New York, T.V.
and newspaper interviews, and
autograph hounds.
James Stein, the students' agent
explained, "It's a fantasy come
true. There's a big market for it,
a big market. Now hopefully,
they'll make a fair amount of
money.
Jessica Reed, a fellow student
and friend of Belur's at Hopkins
declared, "Ashwin is like that
sometimes--he'll pick up an idea
and become entranced with it, not
forgetting it until it has exhausted
him." Rita Sun, another close
friend of Belur's at Hopkins.
agreed. "I'm not really that surprised this happened to Aswhin."

Interest In South African Protest Rallies Wanes
(CPS)—Protests of college investment in companies that do
business in segregationist South
Africa came off as planned last
week on about 50 American campuses, but some protest leaders
think college interest in the issue
may be waning.
Demonstrations at Dartmouth,
Southern Cal, North Carolina,
Wesleyan, Toledo, Texas and
some other campuses were
notably smaller than antiapartheid protests held on the
same campuses last April and last
October.
"I think there's been a decline
in interest in divestment this
fall," says Glenn Maloney, assistant to the dean of students at the
University of Texas at Austin.
Last week's protest drew only
50 students, compared to more
than 300 at a rally last April,
which—like the recent October
rallies—was coordinated as part
of a National Day of Protest staged by the American Committee
on Africa in New York.

Crowd size at the University of
Illinois was down to 50 to 75 people last week, reports political
science major Teresa Cameron,
compared to 150 last spring.
At Wesleyan in Connecticut,
police last April arrested about
130 students involved in a
blockade of the administration
building. Last week, about 20
students staged a sit-in, while 100
others listened quietly to antiapartheid speakers. There were
no arrests.
Dartmouth's anti-apartheid
speeches drew 125 students, professors and local residents,
estimates Dartmouth spokesman
Alex Huppe, compared to "300
to 500 people" last spring.
But Kay McKenzie, a faculty
member and organizer of last
week's demonstration at the
University of Mississippi, says
she's happy with the turnout of
150 students.
"The issue is just catching on
here," she says. "Mississippi is
a very conservative place. They

don't change that quickly."
McKenzie does think the issue
may be waning mostly in places
where it's been big for a few
years now.
Anti-apartheid protests have
been going on on some campuses
since the early 1970's, but
abruptly became a national

phenomenon in January, 1985. In
April and May, 1985, a College
Press Service count found nearly
200 campuses hosting some kind
of anti-apartheid activity. The
American Committee on Africa
estimated about 100 campuses
joined its April, 1986 effort.
Some observers blamed the

weather for last week's diminished turnouts. At Illinois, Cameron
noted the protest came during
midterm's week.
More than 50 schools have
agreed to divest partially or fully
so far in 1986, a record pace.

To the Editor:

the Trustee's vote on divestment
and the Coalition for a Free South
Africa's response failed to ask

conference, and then occupied the

explanation of those actions the

being noticed. They took a back

the Coalition to move so they

To the Editor:
In all the recent controversy
surrounding the JHU Coalition
for a Free South Africa, it is important to remember that there
are two very distinct issues
involved—the actions of the
Coalition and divestment itself.
Many students have voiced the
opinion that, while they favor
divestment, they are opposed to
the means the Coalition has used
to pressure the Trustees to divest.
The problem with this quite
reasonable position is that it
moves the focus of attention.froth
diVestment, which should be the

primary issue at hand, to the
Coalition. Because these people
feel offended or alienated by the
Coalition, they seem to be forgeting that they and the Coalition
share the same goal—alleviating
the suffering of the victims of
apartheid.
The Coalition's methods of
pressuring the Trustees to vote
for divestment may very well offend some members of the JHU
community. But if these members
do favor divestment, why don't
they suggest to the Coalition
other, more acceptable, means of
achieving this important end? The
Coalition has been, and is, willing to listen and respond to opinions from outside of its ranks.
Anyone can come to a Coalition
meeting, and those with serious
suggestions should not fear
ridicule or lack of attention.
The Coalition, though, seems
to be the only group on campus
with any strategy for achieving
divestment. It appears that those
favoring divestment and opposing
the Coalition are content to sit
around and talk about the evils of
apartheid instead of actually doing anything. If for nothing else,
the Coalition should be appreciated for making an effort to
change the status quo in favor of
the oppressed. It may, in the opinions of some, have made some
tactical errors, but at least it is doing something.
I urge the students who share
the Coalition's concern for the
victims of apartheid to put aside
their reservations and talk to
some Coalition members about
divestment. In essence, we all
want the same thing—freedom for
black South Africans—we just
need to settle our differences
about ways of realizing this goal.
Maybe with greater communications and unity on the Hopkins
campus, some real progress can
be made.
Lisa Lindsay

Barnstormers Production: Arsenic and Old Lace
by Loren Fox
by Joseph Kesselring
Directed by David Deboy
Produced by Carol Gerry and
Jim Stofan
The theme of the old Alfred
Hitchcock Hour begins, and the
piano is moved aside to add seats.
Saturday night and it is standing
room only in the L/V room for
the Barnstormers' production of
Arsenic and Old Lace. The
1940's farce by Joseph Kesselring remains a stodgy classic in
old-fashioned American comedy.
In the Barnstormers' production,
the play moves a little stiffly
around the joints, but old as it is,
it gets the laughs out.
The first thing to notice is Andy Angelino's wonderful set. Not
only is there a wall lined with
bookcases, paintings, and three
working doors, but there is actually a second floor--complete
with a carpeted staircase. The
Listening/Viewing
Room
(designed for neither listening nor
viewing) is a terrible theater, but
the Arsenic set transcends even
that.
The play begins in the Brewster
home in Brooklyn. Abby
Brewster (Kelli Midgley) and her
sister Martha (Alice Griffin) live
in the house taking care of their
nephew Teddy (Scott McNamee).
Abby and Martha make chicken
broth for sick neighbors and help

whenever they can, and Teddy
thinks that he is Theodore
Roosevelt. Policemen come over
to collect old toys for the
Christmas fund, and there is a
dead body in the window seat. It's
as nice and cozy as Our Town
turned inside out.
The two aunts are lively, sweet
and overly bubbly, as if they had
stepped out from an imitation
Norman Rockwell. But Abby and
Martha also mix elderberry wine
with arsenic and cyanide, and
feed it to lonely old men looking
to rent a room. They've been doing this some while and there are
now eleven bodies in the cellar,
in graves dug by Teddy, who
thinks he is digging locks for the
Panama Canal. Another nephew,
Mortimer (Vince Li Cata) is a
theater critic and sane (if one can
be both). He is in love with the
Preacher's daughter, Elaine
(Carol Gerry). Mortimer finds
out about the elderberry wine and
decides it is time to stop it. As he
puts it: "This is becoming a very
bad habit."
Arsenic and Old Lace is a play
of double-takes; the ordinary is
shifted just slightly out of focus.
The great joy is the spoof of
mysteries—the audience can
relish in knowing something the
actors don't. Mortimer is a real
sharp-tongued journalist in the
tradition of The Front Page. Li
Cata plays him as a nervous,
quirky intellectual. He makes

wonderful cracks about criticism,
such as, "I can save time if I
write my review on the way to the
theater." Or he says to a colleague, "I was just feeling a
bit. . .Pirandellish."
In Act Two, the other nephew
comes home. Jonathan Brewster
(Chris Barrett) returns after
traveling the world murdering
people. He returns with a jumpy
surgeon known as Dr. Einstein
(Jeremy Golub). In the film,
Einstein was played by Peter
Lorre, but Golub makes the part
his own. Jonathan, who was
made to look like Boris Karloff
after some of Einstein's plastic
surgery, wants to move back
home and set up a plastic surgery
shop. "Practically everybody in
Brooklyn needs a new face," he
explains. These two have brought
their own corpse, and the comedy
ensues.
The aunts work in their own
perfectly logical fashion,
endeavoring to help friendless old
gentlemen find "peace." When
Mortimer says, "There are 12
men in the cellar and you admit
you've poisoned them," Abby
replies: "Yes, I did. But I
wouldn't stoop to lying."
Midgley's great asset is her
voice, fluttering like the old lace
decorating her home. She is just
a slightly better comedienne than
Griffin, who nevertheless is an
excellent, if slightly posed, actress. When the twelfth body is

hidden in the window seat, they
tell Teddy to keep it a secret. He
thinks a moment, then
McNamee's eyes light up, "A
state secret?" McNamee is a
very funny Teddy, not overplaying the role, yet keeping him off
the wall enough so that the audience looks forward to his next
entrance.
Mortimer tries to explain to
Elaine that he can't marry her
because of his heritage. "Insanity runs in my family. In fact, it
practically gallops." There is
good chemistry between them,
though Li Cata (with his Jimmy
Stewart awkwardness) is at first
overpowered by Gerry. Gerry
comes on strong with her be-bop
hairstyle and expressive mouth.
Li Cata, with wild facial expressions, voice cracking and
browline jumping, is a frantically witty Mortimer, yet he lacks
the presence to make a realistic
foil for Jonathan.
As Jonathan, Chris Barrett
fumes, sneers and boils. Unfortunately the play doesn't allow for
his character to explode, and he
is kept within a limited range. Except for some trouble with his
lines, Barrett comes off well. Accolades are due for Jeremy
Golub, a physical actor par excellence. With eyebrows twitching and eyes rolling, Golub
steals almost every scene he is in.
All eyes are on Golub's mimicking of Elaine as Jonathan

threatens her, and the funniest
scene of the night is when Einstein tries to get out of the window
seat.
The supporting cast is competent although the play gives them
little in the way of character.
Glenn White is sufficiently suffocating as a playwriting cop, and
Jason Hanson is bothersome as a
pompous policemen with an innocuous smirk plastered to his
face. The script itself drags a little in parts. Arsenic really is too
long a play, but one sits through
it to see some fine examples of
humor, as when Jonathan
discovers that the aunts have killed twelve men, just as he has.
"Johnny," Einstein says,
"We've been chased all over the
world. And they [Abby and Martha] stayed in Brooklyn and did
just as good as you."
Director David Deboy (who
did last fall's Hot L Baltimore: the
Barnstormers' choice of plays
needs work) paces it a bit too
slowly. There need to be more
coincidences, as when Elaine hits
Jonathan in the face with the
door. Besides some faltering
lights and some fragile props, the
production runs smoothly. Punch
and cookies during the intermission is a nice touch—the Barnstormers have turned in a class
act. So, could theater at Hopkins
finally becoming into its own?
Maybe, but first, have a glass of
elderberry wine.

Scientists at the Johns Hopkins

CF is a relatively common

carry digestive enzymes into the
small intestine.
